standard_metadata.standard_description: Giving quantitative measures of center (median and/or mean) and variability (interquartile range and/or mean absolute deviation), as well as describing any overall pattern and any striking deviations from the overall pattern with reference to the context in which the data were gathered.

question.content: The following box plot shows the number of surfers at each beach in Miami.    **About $75\%$ of beaches in Miami have more than what number of surfers?**

images.alt: A horizontal boxplot is plotted along a horizontal axis marked from 0 to 20, in increments of 1. A left whisker extends from 2 to 8. The box extends from 8 to 15 and is divided into 2 parts by a vertical line segment at 13. The right whisker extends from 15 to 19. All values estimated.

hints.content: Each **quartile** helps us split the data points into fourths.  Value | Approximate fraction of data above this value | Approximate percentage of data above this value -|-:|-: Minimum | All | $100\%$ $Q_1$ | $\dfrac{3}{4}$ | $75\%$ Median |  $\dfrac{2}{4}$, which is $\dfrac{1}{2}$ | $50\%$ $Q_3$ | $\dfrac{1}{4}$ | $25\%$ Maximum | None | $0\%$  [[☃ explanation 1]]
$\maroonD{8}$ beaches is the first quartile quartile. So about $\tealE{75\%}$ of beaches in Miami have $\maroonD{8}$ or more surfers.  [[☃ image 2]]

images.alt: A horizontal boxplot is plotted along a horizontal axis marked from 0 to 20, in increments of 1. A left whisker extends from 2 to 8. The box extends from 8 to 15 and is divided into 2 parts by a vertical line segment at 13. A right whisker extends from 15 to 19. The two whiskers and the two parts of the box are each labeled 25%. The vertical line segment at 8 is highlighted. The three 25% labels to the right of that vertical line segment is highlighted. All values estimated.

hints.content: About $75\%$ of beaches in Miami have more than $8$ surfers.
